coredata.dc:title: Modification of solid electrolyte interface layer between PVDF-based electrolyte and lithium anode

coredata.dc:description: Poly(vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF)-based polymer electrolytes (PEs) with good electrochemical performance and processability as well as low-cost advantage, have great potential applications in solid-state lithium (Li) metal batteries (SSLMBs). PVDF-based PEs are generally produced by employing a solution-casting approach with N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) as the solvent, accompanied by the formation of [DMF-Li+] complex, which facilitates the Li-ion transport. However, the residual DMF can react continuously with lithium (Li) metal, thereby deteriorating the interface layer in the middle of the PVDF-based PEs and Li anodes. Herein, we introduce propylene carbonate (PC) into the PVDF-based PEs to regulate the solvation structure and stabilize the interface layer between the PEs and Li anodes. PC accelerates the dissociation of lithium oxalyldifluoroborate (LiODFB). Consequently, “lithium propylene dicarbonate (LPDC)‒B-O″ oligomer forms as the interfacial layer with high tenacity, homogeneity, and densification, which improves the interfacial contact and suppresses the continuous reaction between the residual DMF and Li anode. We further demonstrate that the PVDF-based PE prepared with DMF-PC mix-solvents shows improved room-temperature ionic conductivity (1.18 × 10−3 S/cm), enhanced stability against electrodes, and superior cycling performance in LiCoO2-based SSLMBs (maintaining 84 % of the initial discharge capacity after 300 cycles).

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Digital images of the gradual evolution of polished Li foils (16 mm in diameter and 450 μm in thickness) during the reaction with (a) pure DMF, (b) pure PC, (c) DMF-PVDF (0.01 g/mL) solution, (d) PC-PVDF (0.01 g/mL) solution, (e) DMF-PVDF (0.01 g/mL) +1 mol/L LiODFB solution, (f) PC-PVDF (0.01 g/mL) +1 mol/L LiODFB solution, (g) DMF + PC (98:2 in volume ratio)PVDF (0.01 g/mL) +1 mol/L LiODFB solution.

Digital images of several (a) DMF-PVDF- and (b) PC-PVDF-Li salts mixtures after one day of reacting with a polished Li foil. (Right part: the structural diagrams of DMF and PC molecules.) (c) Raman spectra of the solutions before and after the reaction with a Li foil. (d) Raman spectra of the DMF-based solutions after one day of reaction with a Li foil.

(a) Photograph of the PVDF-LiODFB-DMF + PC electrolyte and corresponding (b) top- and (c) side-view SEM images. (d) EDS mapping image of B element in the PVDF-LiODFB-DMF + PC electrolyte. Distribution of DMF and PC in the PVDF-LiODFB-DMF + PC electrolyte shown by Raman mapping of the (e) 941 cm−1 (PC) and (f) 674 cm−1 (DMF) wavenumbers.

(a) Ionic conductivity, (b) electrochemical stability window, (c) CCD of the PVDF-LiODFB-DMF and PVDF-LiODFB-DMF + PC electrolytes. Cycling performances of the Li||PVDF-LiODFB-DMF||Li and Li||PVDF-LiODFB-DMF + PC||Li symmetric cells at 25 °C under (d) 0.1 mA/cm2 and 0.1 mA·h/cm2 and (e) 0.2 mA/cm2 and 0.2 mA·h/cm2. The insets in (d) show the enlarged voltage−time curves.

(a, b) Top-view and corresponding (c, d) FIB-SEM images of the Li electrodes disassembled from the Li symmetric cells with PVDF-LiODFB-DMF and PVDF-LiODFB-DMF + PC electrolytes after ten cycles at a current density of 0.1 mA/cm2 and a capacity density of 0.1 mA·h/cm2, respectively. (e) XPS spectra of Li 1s, C 1s, and O 1s of the interfacial layers between PVDF-based electrolytes and Li electrodes. (f) B 1s XPS spectra on the surface of the cycled Li foils after 0, 40, 80 s, and 120 s Ar sputtering.

(a) Cycling performances at 0.2 C of LCO||PVDF-LiODFB-DMF||Li and LCO||PVDF-LiODFB-DMF + PC||Li cells. (b) Charge−discharge curve and (c) dQ/dV curve of LCO||PVDF-LiODFB-DMF + PC||Li cell. (d) Rate performances of LCO||PVDF-LiODFB-DMF||Li and LCO||PVDF-LiODFB-DMF + PC||Li cells.

head.ce:title: Modification of solid electrolyte interface layer between PVDF-based electrolyte and lithium anode

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Poly(vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF)-based polymer electrolytes (PEs) with good electrochemical performance and processability as well as low-cost advantage, have great potential applications in solid-state lithium (Li) metal batteries (SSLMBs). PVDF-based PEs are generally produced by employing a solution-casting approach with N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) as the solvent, accompanied by the formation of [DMF-Li+] complex, which facilitates the Li-ion transport. However, the residual DMF can react continuously with lithium (Li) metal, thereby deteriorating the interface layer in the middle of the PVDF-based PEs and Li anodes. Herein, we introduce propylene carbonate (PC) into the PVDF-based PEs to regulate the solvation structure and stabilize the interface layer between the PEs and Li anodes. PC accelerates the dissociation of lithium oxalyldifluoroborate (LiODFB). Consequently, “lithium propylene dicarbonate (LPDC)‒B-O″ oligomer forms as the interfacial layer with high tenacity, homogeneity, and densification, which improves the interfacial contact and suppresses the continuous reaction between the residual DMF and Li anode. We further demonstrate that the PVDF-based PE prepared with DMF-PC mix-solvents shows improved room-temperature ionic conductivity (1.18 × 10−3 S/cm), enhanced stability against electrodes, and superior cycling performance in LiCoO2-based SSLMBs (maintaining 84 % of the initial discharge capacity after 300 cycles).

ce:section.ce:para: Lithium (Li) metal batteries (LMBs), thanks to the low redox potential (−3.04 V) and high theoretical specific capacity (3,860 mA·h/g) of Li anode, are a prospective candidate for the upcoming energy storage devices [1,2]. However, safety and performance issues arise when organic liquid electrolytes are used in LMBs, due to their leakage, flammability, poor chemical stability, and lithium dendrites growth [3,4]. Solid-state lithium metal batteries (SSLMBs), where solid-state electrolytes (SSEs) are in place of liquid electrolytes, show intrinsic improved safety [5]. The optimal compatibility between the SSEs and high-voltage or manganese-rich cathode materials (e.g., LiMn2O4, LiNi0·5Mn1·5O4, Li1·2Ni0·13Co0·13Mn0·54O2) also enables increased energy density and reduced cost of the batteries. This is of significant importance for the application and development of SSLMBs, especially in the field of electric vehicles.

To improve the electrochemical performance of SSLMBs, much attention was devoted to two pressing concerns: The high-performance solid-state electrolytes (SSEs) and the construction of a stable interface between SSEs and Li anodes. Currently, the most widely investigated SSEs include oxides [6], sulfides [7], halides [8], and polymer-based electrolytes [9]. Oxide electrolytes exhibit high ionic conductivity, superior thermal and mechanical stabilities, and wide electrochemical stability window [6]. However, poor interfacial contact with electrodes and a high sintering temperature (>1,000 °C) severely restrict their application [10]. Sulfide electrolytes have gained significant interest recently because of their low processing temperature, excellent deformability, and ultra-high ionic conductivity (1–10 mS/cm) [11]. The main disadvantages of sulfide electrolytes when widely applied in SSLMBs are their high price, poor thermodynamic stability, moisture sensitivity, and narrow electrochemical window [12]. In recent years, halide electrolytes stand out for their considerable ionic conductivity, wide electrochemical stability window [13], ideal compatibility with commercial oxide cathodes, and even a universal wet-chemistry synthesis strategy [14]. Unfortunately, the high valence state metal elements in halide SSEs induce the poor reduction stability [15]. Compared with the aforementioned inorganic electrolytes, polymer electrolytes (PEs) with good electrode compatibility, ease of mass production, and low cost have demonstrated satisfying commercial application potential. Several typical PEs have been widely investigated, including poly(ethylene oxide) (PEO)-based [16], polyacrylonitrile (PAN)-based [17], poly(propylene carbonate) (PPC)-based [18], and poly(vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF)-based [19–21]. Among them, PVDF-based electrolytes are widely considered as optimal candidates because of their high dielectric constant, good Li salt dissociation ability, excellent thermal stability, and favorable mechanical properties of PVDF [22,23].

As ever reported as a buffer layer to enhance the interfacial stability with Li anode, pure PVDF demonstrates good stability against Li metal [24]. Nevertheless, building a stable interface layer against Li anodes is still a critical challenge for PVDF-based PEs. The solution-casting method is commonly employed to prepare PVDF-based PEs, utilizing N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) as the solvent. DMF can complex with Li+ and form [DMF-Li+] complexes to facilitate the Li-ion transport. Unfortunately, the residual DMF continuously reacts with Li metal, leading to interface degradation and ultimately accelerating overall failure of LMBs [25,26]. To form stable interface layers between the PVDF-based PEs and Li anodes, several strategies have been applied, including controlling Li salts, adding inorganic fillers, and replacing DMF with other solvents. For example, Zhang et al. [27] utilized different Li salts to prepare PVDF-based electrolytes and demonstrated that the PVDF−LiN(SO2F)2 electrolyte could establish a stable interface layer in situ, effectively inhibiting the growth of Li dendrite on the Li anode surface. To suppress the side reaction between DMF and Li anodes, Yang et al. [21] added Li1·4Al0·4Ti1·6(PO4)3 (LATP) nanowires with an anchoring effect on DMF solvent into the PVDF-based electrolyte. Thus, the as-prepared PVDF-LATP-based composite electrolyte showed the improved electrochemical performance (e.g., 700 h cycling of repeated Li plating–stripping under the current density of 0.5 mA/cm2). Replacing DMF with a solvent stable against Li metal is the most direct way to improve the interfacial stability towards Li metal of PVDF-based PEs. Accordingly, the PVDF-based PEs prepared with other high-polar solvents, such as N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMAc) [26], N-methylpyrrolidone (NMP) [26], and dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) [28], have been synthesized but with disappointing results. For example, the Li symmetric cell with PVDF-NMP electrolyte exhibits a significantly higher polarization voltage and shorter cycling time compared to the case of DMF solvent [26]. Propylene carbonate (PC) is an ideal solvent for PEs due to its good electrochemical stability against Li metal and the decent dielectric constant [29,30]. PC may be beneficial for improving the electrochemical performances of PVDF-based PEs, but so far, using PC to prepare PVDF-based PEs has not been reported, which may be due to the poor solubility to PVDF of PC.

In this work, for the first time, we applied PC and DMF as a mix-solvent system to prepare a PVDF-based PE that shows excellent electrochemical stability against Li metal. The effects of PC on the electrolyte-Li metal interface evolution and related mechanisms were explored. The study showed that PC can regulate the solvation structure and accelerate the dissociation of lithium oxalyldifluoroborate (LiODFB). Subsequently, PC and LiODFB would decompose on the Li anode surface, and the organic decomposition compounds would complex with typical inorganic compounds to form an organic-inorganic interface layer with remarkable tenacity, homogeneity, and densification. This layer enhanced the interfacial contact and suppressed the continuous reaction between residual DMF and Li anodes. In addition, the comprehensive performances of the electrolyte prepared with the mixed solvent were also evaluated. The electrolyte prepared with DMF-PC mix-solvent system delivered a higher room-temperature (at 25 °C) ionic conductivity (1.18 × 10−3 S/cm), enhanced mechanical properties and wider electrochemical window, all of which considerably enhanced the cycling performance of SSLMBs. This work provided a straightforward method for optimizing the solid interface layer between PVDF-based PEs and Li metals, thereby increasing the potential of PVDF-based electrolytes for board utilization in SSLMBs.

PVDF 5130 (Solvay, Solef 5130) and LiODFB (Meryer Chemical Technology, 99%) were vacuum-dried for 24 h at 80 °C before use. The PVDF-LiODFB (1:1 in mass ratio) electrolytes were made through a slurry casting-drying method as reported before [19], and the whole preparation procedure was carried out in a dry room with a dew point of −45 °C. To prepare PVDF-LiODFB-DMF or PVDF-LiODFB-DMF + PC slurries, PVDF (3 g) and LiODFB (3 g) were dissolved in a 40 mL DMF or a DMF-PC mixture (98:2 in volume ratio), followed by mechanical stirring for 12 h. After that, the slurries were dried in a blast drying oven at 25 °C for 2 h after casting onto a glass plate via a blade to prepare PVDF-LiODFB-DMF and PVDF-LiODFB-DMF + PC electrolytes. The electrolyte membranes have an average thickness of around 40 μm.

The electrolyte samples were examined using high-resolution field-emission scanning electron microscopy (Zeiss, Merlin Compact) to obtain scanning electron micrographs (SEM) and energy dispersive spectral (EDS) mapping images of the PVDF-based electrolyte samples. SEM was also applied to observe the cross-sectional SEM images of the PVDF-based electrolyte membranes after being subjected to freezing and fracturing in liquid nitrogen. Raman imaging microscope (Thermo Fisher, Dxr2xi) was utilized to characterize the distribution of residual DMF and PC in the electrolytes. The observation area was 10 μm × 10 μm. The topography of the cycled Li electrodes' surface and cross-section was observed using dual-beam focused ion beam scanning electron microscopy (FIB-SEM, Zeiss Merlin, Crossbeam 340). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Ulvac-Phi, PHI Quantera II) was applied to qualitatively characterize the chemical constituents of the interface layer in the middle of the PVDF-based electrolytes and Li electrodes. The depth profiling of XPS was obtained by Argon ion (Ar+) sputtering. Raman spectra were obtained with a Raman spectrometer (HORIBA, LabRAM HR Evolution). The thermal stability of the electrolytes was examined by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA, Mettler Toledo, TGA2 SF). Under an Ar gas ambience, the TGA measurement was carried out with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Rigaku D/max-2500 diffractometer running at 40 kV and 200 mA was used to gain the X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the electrolyte samples. A universal testing machine (Dongguan Zhiqu Precise Instrument Co., LTD, ZQ-990 A) was applied to determine the tensile and puncture strength of the PVDF-based PEs with an area of 20 mm × 50 mm, operating at a stretching speed of 100 mm/min. The puncture nail has a diameter of 1 mm.

The CR2032-type coin batteries without liquid electrolytes were assembled in an Ar-filled glovebox (Mikrouna, 2440) with oxygen and water concentrations below 0.1 ppm (ppm is the volume of pollutants contained in one million volumes of air), in order to examine the electrochemical properties of the electrolytes. The ionic conductivities (σ) were measured using stainless steel (SS) symmetric cells (SS||PVDF-based electrolyte||SS) in the frequency range of 1 MHz to 1 Hz via an electrochemical workstation (Shanghai CH Instruments Co., Ltd, CHI604E). To investigate the temperature dependence of the σ of the PVDF-based PEs, measurements were conducted at different temperatures ranging from 0 to 100 °C. Then, the activation energy E a was calculated via the Arrhenius equation σ(T) = A exp(−E a/RT), incorporating a pre-exponential factor (A), molar gas constant (R), and absolute temperature (T). The electrochemical stabilities of the electrolytes were tested by performing linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) tests on Li||electrolyte||SS cells at a scan rate of 0.1 mV/s using Zahner-elecktrik Zennium Pro. The interfacial stabilities towards Li anodes of the PVDF-based electrolytes were assessed by assembling Li symmetric cells (Li||PVDF-based electrolyte||Li) and testing them at current densities of 0.1 mA/cm2 and 0.2 mA/cm2. Additionally, step-increasing current density tests were performed on Li symmetric cells with each cycle lasting for 1 h to quantitatively assess the critical current density (CCD) of PVDF-based PEs.

SSLMBs were constructed using a Li foil, a PVDF-LiODFB-DMF or a PVDF-LiODFB-DMF + PC electrolyte membrane, and a LiCoO2 (LCO) or LiNi0·8Co0·1Mn0·1O2 (NCM811) composite cathode. The cathode slurry, comprised of LCO powder (Beijing Easpring Material Technology Co., Ltd) or NCM811 powder (BASF-Shanshan energy Co. Ltd), super P carbon black (Timcal), PVDF 5130, and lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide (LiTFSI, Aladdin, 99%) in mass ratio of 85:5:5:5, was mixed and homogenized in NMP solvent. LiTFSI was chosen for its superior thermal stability and humidity resistance over LiODFB. After being coated on aluminum foil, the mixture underwent a drying process in a vacuum oven at 110 °C for 12 h to produce cathode sheets. Subsequently, a circular cathode (Φ14 mm) with an active material mass loading of ∼2.0 mg/cm2 was cut off from the as-prepared cathode sheet for assembling a SSLMB. The cycling performances of the Li symmetric cells and SSLMBs at room temperature (25 °C) were evaluated by a battery test system (C2001A, Land).

ce:section.ce:section-title: Chemical stability against Li metal of DMF and PC-based solutions
ce:section.ce:para: The chemical stability of DMF and PC-based solutions against Li metal was investigated by dropping various solutions onto the surface of polished Li foils and monitoring the subsequent reactions. As shown in Fig. 1 a and b, no obvious color-change reactions were observed when pure DMF or PC were applied to the Li foil for 25 min. However, after reacting with Li metal for 2 h, the DMF solution displayed a faint yellow color. When the reaction time was prolonged to 4 h, the DMF solution showed a deep orange color, along with the formation of bubbles (Fig. S1). However, the chemical stability against Li metal significantly changed when PVDF was dissolved in DMF and PC. The Li metal immediately reacted with DMF-PVDF solution and turned black (Fig. 1c), while it remained unchanged in the case of the PC-PVDF solution (Fig. 1d). The apparent color change in the case of DMF-PVDF solution can be attributed to the formation of conjugated carbon-carbon double bonds resulting from the dehydrofluorination of PVDF. As previously reported, DMF has been found to react with Li metal and decompose into free radicals, which subsequently attack PVDF and induce dehydrofluorination [26]. Intuitively, PC is chemically stable to Li metal in PVDF-based solutions, while DMF induces dramatic reactions on the surface of Li metal. After introducing LiODFB into the aforementioned solutions, the responses between the DMF-based solutions and Li metal weakened, and the color changed into canary instead of black (Fig. 1e). The PC-PVDF-LiODFB solution proved no noticeable color change with the polished Li foil as well as the above PC-based solutions (Fig. 1f). Additionally, the mere introduction of a small amount of PC (2%, in volume) demonstrates remarkable effectiveness in inhibiting the reaction between DMF and Li metal (Fig. 1g), which may be attributed to the preferential formation of a stable and dense interface layer with Li metal by PC, thereby suppressing the continuous reaction between DMF and Li metal. The DMF + PC-PVDF-LiODFB solution maintains its original color even after reacting with the polished Li foil for 4 h (Fig. S2). Moreover, the DMF-PVDF solution with LiODFB appeared the slightest color change after reacting with the polished Li foil, compared to those with lithium bis(fluorosulfonyl)imide (LiFSI) and LiTFSI (Fig. S3).

To gain deeper insights into the reaction mechanism with Li anodes, the color and Raman spectra of the DMF and PC-based solutions were compared before and after reacting with Li anodes for one day. After reacting for one day, the DMF-PVDF solution presented a black color (Fig. 2 a). Additionally, the appearance of characteristic carbon D (1,353 cm−1) and G (1,581 cm−1) peaks associated with conjugated carbon-carbon double bonds signifies the dehydrofluorination of PVDF [31,32]. Meanwhile, the absence of the peak at 2,933 cm−1 attributed to the carbon-hydrogen bond of DMF indicates the decomposition of DMF into free radicals (such as ·CH3) during the continuous reaction with Li metal as mentioned above (Fig. 2c). In contrast, with the addition of LiODFB, the solution color changed to a deep orange color instead of black and remained the peak at 2,933 cm−1 in the Raman spectrum, indicating that LiODFB suppressed the chemical reaction. In the case of PC–PVDF-based solutions, the color remained unchanged (Fig. 2b), and Raman spectra remained consistent during the reaction, further verifying PC is chemically stable against Li metal. To further clarify the influence of Li salts, the Raman spectra of DMF-based solutions after reacting with Li foils for one day were compared (Fig. 2d). LiTFSI exhibited a poor capability to suppress the side reaction against Li metal as evidenced by the similar Raman spectra of the DMF-PVDF solutions with and without LiTFSI. On the other hand, both DMF-PVDF solutions containing LiODFB or LiFSI still had a peak at 2,933 cm−1 in the Raman spectra. Since LiFSI is known to be stable with Li anodes [27], the result observed here proves that LiODFB exhibits excellent chemical stability towards Li metal and the ideal ability to inhibit the side reactions between DMF and Li anodes effectively. In addition, LiODFB possesses a wide electrochemical window and can tolerate high-voltage cathodes [33,34], making it an ideal alternative Li salt for PVDF-based PEs.

In benefit of the intrinsic film-forming advantage of PVDF [35], the PVDF-LiODFB-DMF + PC electrolyte can be easily scaled up for production. Fig. 3 a shows a transparent and flexible PVDF-based electrolyte membrane with a size of ∼15 cm × 15 cm. The top-view SEM image in Fig. 3b demonstrates the dense structure and smooth surface of the PVDF-LiODFB-DMF + PC electrolyte. The PVDF-LiODFB-DMF electrolyte membrane, however, contains many pores ranging in diameter from 0.5 μm to 2.0 μm (Figs. S4a and S4b). The cross-sectional SEM image (Fig. 3c) shows that the PVDF-LiODFB-DMF + PC membrane is dense, with a thickness of only ∼40 μm, indicating that the electrolyte has excellent potential in flexible SSLMBs with higher energy density requiring reduced thickness [36]. EDS mapping images of the PVDF-LiODFB-DMF + PC electrolyte are presented in Fig. 3d and S5, confirming the uniform distribution of PVDF, LiODFB, and DMF in the membrane. Additionally, Raman mapping was performed on the PVDF-LiODFB-DMF + PC membrane to generate a spatial representation of the distribution of PC and DMF within the PVDF matrix. The characteristic peaks for analysis were 941 for PC and 674 cm−1 for DMF. As shown in Fig. 3e and f, the distribution of PC and DMF is homogeneous in the case of DMF + PC-based electrolytes. The dense and uniform structure of PVDF-LiODFB-DMF + PC film can ensure the continuity of ion transport channels, thereby contributing to high ionic conductivity [3,19].

The ionic conductivities (σ) of the PVDF-LiODFB-DMF and PVDF-LiODFB-DMF + PC electrolytes were measured using electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (Fig. S6), and the results were compared in Fig. 4 a. With an equivalent quantity of LiODFB, the DMF + PC-based electrolyte has a higher ionic conductivity of 1.18 × 10−3 S/cm, and a lower activation energy E a (0.218 eV) at room temperature (25 °C) than those of the DMF-based one (1.08 × 10−3 S/cm, 0.262 eV), both indicating enhanced migration of Li+ in the DMF+PC-based electrolyte. The TGA curves (Fig. S7a) demonstrate similar residual solvent contents in DMF and DMF + PC-based electrolytes. Furthermore, the Raman spectra in Fig. S7b show that all residual DMF and PC molecules are present in bound states. As a result, differences in electrochemical properties should not be ascribed to the bound solvent [26], but rather to other elements (morphology, crystallinity, and so on). As evident from Fig. 3 and S4, the PVDF-LiODFB-DMF + PC electrolyte exhibits denser morphology, which offers advantages in improving ionic conductivity. The XRD spectra presented in Fig. S7c indicate that the electrolyte with PC has a broader full width at half-maximum (fwhm) of the diffraction peak (∼21°) than that without PC, suggesting lower crystallinity. It is widely acknowledged that improving the ionic conduction of PEs can be effectively achieved by increasing the proportion of non-crystalline regions [37].

The LSV test results (Fig. 4b) were compared for the PVDF-LiODFB-DMF and PVDF-LiODFB-DMF + PC electrolytes to investigate the influence of PC on electrochemical stability windows. The current of the PVDF-LiODFB-DMF electrolyte initiates at 4.35 V as a result of the decomposition of the [DMF-Li+] mixture [19,26], gradually escalating within the range of 4.35 V and 4.75 V. Conversely, the oxidative decomposition of the DMF + PC-based electrolyte starts at 4.5 V and accelerates above 4.8 V, indicating its suitability for SSLMBs with high-voltage cathodes. To assess the CCD of the two PVDF-based electrolytes, Li symmetric cells underwent step-increased current density tests at 25 °C. As shown in Fig. 4c, the CCD of the electrolyte with PC is doubled compared to the electrolyte without PC (1.0 mA/cm2 vs. 0.5 mA/cm2). Furthermore, the Li symmetric cell containing DMF + PC-based electrolyte exhibits longer cycle duration and lower Li plating/stripping overpotential at current densities of 0.1 mA/cm2 and 0.2 mA/cm2 than that with the DMF-based electrolyte (Fig. 4d, e). The poor cycling performances of the Li symmetric cell with the DMF-based electrolyte can be attributed to the inadequate stability of the DMF-based electrolyte against Li metal. In-situ electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) revealed a notable increase in the impedance of the Li||PVDF-LiODFB-DMF||Li cell, coinciding with an open circuit at 46 h, indicating an unmanageable and irreversible change of the interface layer (Figs. S8a and b). In contrast, for the case of DMF + PC-based electrolyte, the polarization voltage and impedance of the Li symmetric cell increased slightly during the first five cycles. They remained relatively constant thereafter, which may be ascribed to a stable interface layer formed in the middle of the DMF + PC-based electrolyte and Li metal (Figs. S8c and d). In addition, the electrolyte with PC also shows better tensile strength (∼4.3 MPa), puncture strength (∼4.2 MPa), and elongation than those of the electrolyte without PC (Fig. S9). These mechanical characteristics have advantageous effects in inhibiting the penetration of Li dendrite [7,38,39].

After cycling the Li symmetric cells assembled with the two PVDF-based electrolytes for ten cycles, the Li electrodes were disassembled from the cells and further characterized via dual-beam FIB-SEM. As shown in Fig. 5 a, a nonuniform and leaky interface layer was formed in the middle of the DMF-based electrolyte and Li metal, as evidenced by the rough and visibly fractured surface of the Li metal. For the case of DMF + PC-based electrolyte, however, the Li electrode surface is smooth, and no cracks are observed (Fig. 5b). Moreover, as shown in Fig. 5c and d and the DMF-based electrolyte formed a much thicker interface layer against Li metal than the DMF + PC-based electrolyte (437 nm vs. 216 nm). To investigate the components of these interface layers, XPS was further performed on the peeled-off Li electrodes (Fig. 5e and f). In the Li 1s spectra, a characteristic peak of metallic Li (53.1 eV) is observed for the electrolyte with PC, but it is not detected for the electrolyte without PC. This indicates that adding PC effectively mitigated interfacial reactions between DMF and Li electrode [40], which aligns with the FIB-SEM results (Fig. 5a–d). In the C 1s spectra, a signal of lithium propylene dicarbonate (LPDC, 288.7 eV) appears in the case of DMF + PC-based electrolyte, which should be generated from the decomposition of PC [41,42]. LPDC is a central component of the solid electrolyte interface (SEI) layer for the case of PC-based liquid electrolytes. It plays an essential role in stabilizing interfaces between electrolytes and anodes [42]. Moreover, the O 1s spectrum of DMF + PC-based electrolyte shows the signal of the BO bond, which indicates the formation of complex mesh compounds based on the BO bond (534.5 eV) [43]. The SEI layer may be strengthened and given exceptional tenacity, uniformity, and densification by combining the BO-based compounds with reductive products of solvents (such as LPDC) [43–45]. The emergence of BO should be ascribed to PC with high dielectric constant [29], which can promote the dissociation of LiODFB and further generate a stable interface layer. The depth profiling of B 1s spectra is consistent with the analysis of the O 1s spectrum. The majority of the chemical state of B element for the case of DMF + PC-based electrolyte is the BO bond (191.9 eV) [43,46] and BF bond (193.6 eV) [47] derived from residual LiODFB only present on the surface of the cycled Li anode, while only BF bond exists for the case without PC. Therefore, PC can work together with LiODFB and form a gel-like “LPDC‒B–O oligomer”-based compound, which may strengthen typical inorganic compounds and help to build an organic-inorganic SEI layer with good tenacity and density. The organic-inorganic SEI layer can improve the solid-solid interfacial contact and suppress the continuous reactions between residual DMF and Li anodes.

SSLMBs were assembled and tested in a configuration with a Li anode, a PVDF-LiODFB-DMF or PVDF-LiODFB-DMF + PC electrolyte, and a LCO-based composite cathode. With an active material mass loading of 2.0 mg/cm2, the LCO||DMF-based electrolyte||Li cell exhibits an initial specific discharge capacity of 109.2 mA·h/g at 0.2 C (Fig. 6 a). After around 75 cycles, the discharge capacity and Coulombic efficiency (CE) of the cell drop rapidly. This may be attributed to the formation of a thick and uneven interface layer between Li anodes and electrolytes (Fig. 5a and c). On the other hand, as shown in Fig. 6b and S10a, the LCO||DMF + PC-based electrolyte||Li cell exhibits relatively low polarization and exceptional long-term cycling performance, retaining 84% of the initial capacity after 300 cycles (1st: 139.2 mA·h/g, 300th: 117.1 mA·h/g). The longer cycling duration and higher discharge capacities of the LCO||DMF + PC-based electrolyte||Li cell should be ascribed to the better stability towards Li metal and a high room-temperature ionic conductivity of the DMF + PC-based electrolyte. Additionally, Fig. 6c and S10b show the differential capacity profiles of the LCO||Li cells with DMF- and DMF + PC-based electrolytes. The characteristic peaks are observed at 3.95 V (1# peak) vs. Li/Li+ during charging and 3.9 V (2# peak) during discharging. For the DMF + PC-based electrolyte, the height of the 1# peak remains relatively constant during the cycling process, indicating the minimal loss of active materials and specific capacity [48]. Additionally, the position of 1# and 2# peaks barely shift, indicating a small increase in the battery's polarization [49]. For the DMF-based electrolyte, however, the height of the 1# peak declines continuously along with the significant shift of 1# and 2# peaks, suggesting a significant loss of specific capacity and an increase of the battery polarization. Similarly, the NCM811-based SSLMB with the DMF + PC-based electrolyte exhibits a higher discharge capacity (Fig. S11a) and a relatively low polarization (Fig. S11b) compared to that with the DMF-based electrolyte. Moreover, the LCO-based SSLMB with the PVDF-LiODFB-DMF + PC membrane also delivers better rate performance. At different rates of 0.2, 0.3, 0.5, 1.0, 2.0 C, and 5.0 C, the LCO||DMF + PC-based electrolyte||Li cell outperforms the battery with the DMF-based electrolyte, delivering high capacities of 138.8, 134.8, 128.9, 120.3, 110.6 mA·h/g, and 94.1 mA·h/g, respectively (Fig. 6d).

The addition of PC as a co-solvent in the preparation process of PVDF-based PEs has led to significant improvements in their electrochemical properties and stability against Li anodes. First, the introduced PC could raise the ionic conductivity by decreasing the crystallinity of PVDF and accelerating the dissociation of Li salt. Adding PC can also give the PVDF-based PE with improved mechanical strength and a widened electrochemical stability window. Second, PC can significantly improve the electrochemical stability of the electrolyte towards Li metal. Partial decomposition of PC and LiODFB on the surface of Li metal leads to the formation of a “LPDC‒B–O oligomer”-based compound. The “LPDC‒B–O oligomer”-based compound works together with typical inorganic compounds and helps to build an organic-inorganic SEI layer with great tenacity, homogeneity, and densification. The organic-inorganic SEI layer improves the solid-solid interfacial contact and suppresses the continuous reaction between Li metal and residual [DMF-Li+] complex. As a result, Li symmetric cells assembled with the PVDF-LiODFB-DMF + PC electrolyte show longer cycling time and lower polarization. The LCO-based and NCM811-based SSLMBs with such PVDF-based electrolyte exhibit much-improved cycling stability.

ce:biography.ce:simple-para: Ying Liang received her Bachelor's degree from College of Polymer Science and Engineering in Sichuan University in 2020. She is now a Ph.D. student supervised by Prof. Nan in Tsinghua University. Her current research focuses on halide-polymer composite electrolytes for solid-state lithium batteries.

Xue Zhang is currently a director of the research department of Qingtao (Kunshan) Energy Development Co. Ltd. She received her Ph.D. degree in School of Materials Science and Engineering at Tsinghua University in 2020. Her research mainly focuses on solid electrolytes and solid-state lithium batteries.

Ce-Wen Nan is a Professor of School of Materials Science and Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing, China. Before joining the faculty of Tsinghua University in 1999, he had worked in Wuhan University of Technology, China, since 1985. He was elected to the Chinese Academy of Sciences in 2011 and as a Fellow of TWAS –the academy of sciences for the developing world in 2012. His recent research focuses on solid state electrolytes, multiferroic materials, polymer-based composites, and thermoelectric oxides.
